Bill B writes:

"The idea that the HRW report isn't a report because it was published before the UN report is ludicrous."

How's this for a resolution?

You've provided a link to the HRW "report." Let others click on that link and see for themselves whether they agree with you or with me. I contend that HRW simply took publicly available information – including none of the UN's findings, which hadn't been published yet – and speculated that Assad did it. You contend that HRW came up with its own facts and reached that conclusion. Let readers who care to figure this out read the HRW "report" and decide for themselves who's correct.

As for the UN report, the careful reader will notice, and I assume you're honest enough to acknowledge, that it does not even speculate, much less conclude, which side carried out the attacks. You cite it, as if it supports your position, but it really doesn't. I suspect you know that, but are counting on other readers not to know it.

Since I'm the one who linked to the reports, I clearly have no problem with people reading them. I did not contend that the HRW report came up with its own facts, but did state that there was no reason to believe that its factual predicates were unreliable or that there was anything intrinsically unreliable about its analysis. If any interested reader wants to show which factual assertions in the HRW report are contradicted by the UN report, I'm sure their posts would be eagerly read.

My reason for citing to the UN report was to rebut your contention regarding the warhead capacity of the two different targets, which you used to establish a greater likelihood that the rebels were culpable.

:"but are counting on other readers not to know it."
Again, the person who made it easier for readers to actually read both reports is the person less likely to be banking on the lack of knowledge of other readers.

Delivery drones may seem unlikely to harm anyone... until one realizes that their command executive and flight control systems will be designed by software engineers, who scorn physical reality as a sordid preoccupation of the lower classes.  ("Oh, it strayed off course and crashed into your grandma?  You just aren't intelligent enough to appreciate this product's elegant design.  We'll have to 'educate our customer base' to embrace these features.")

Delivery drones are unlikely to harm anyone except UPS drivers, and snoop drones can hardly exceed the detail we see on Google Earth Pro (unless you're the CIA).

The real concern is drones' inevitable weaponization, on the heels of their terrifying deployment in places like Afghanistan and Yemen. Before long, those tribesmen will be able to buy their own attack drones on the international arms market, along with security divisions of oil, timber, and gas companies.

These days, bombs delivered by drones can be easily pinned on warlike nations who have the technical ability to deploy them. This will not be the case in the future, and there will be no discernible footprint. A few months ago, a Marine officer in a Yucca Valley bar told me that drone technology is actually quite simple, especially the software, which can be controlled from a smart phone. We've known how to build planes and bombs for a hundred years, so a sky full of robotic assassins is coming soon, to a combat theater near you. There is unlikely to be a discernible footprint, as the drones will be mass produced, like guns sold at Walmart.

The trigger is going to be climate disruption, as famine and chaos will drive citizen improvisation. There will be no effective laws to prevent this.

The best prevention would be to see global political leadership abandon the pursuit of money, and begin to respect life on earth, including people. Then, rogue robots would be manageable rogues. Hey, we can dream, right?

@RobCF, Rob American, and @QP - (PART II)

"These anti-gun nuts think that civilians can even own an assault rifle."

Who can blame us? "Assault weapon" is a political and legal term referring to different types of firearms and weapons, and has differing meanings, usages and purposes.

"Assault weapon" may refer to anti-tank or anti-material explosive based weapons used by the military, like the SMAW portable rocket launcher.

And the term "assault weapon" is often conflated with "assault rifle," which refers only to military rifles capable of selective fire, including fully automatic fire and/or burst fire. In the US, fully automatic firearms are heavily restricted and regulated by federal laws (1934 NFA and the Firearm Owners Protection Act of 1986), as well as by state and local laws.

In discussions about firearms laws and politics in the US, an assault weapon is most commonly defined as a semi-automatic firearm possessing certain cosmetic, ergonomic, or construction features similar to those of military firearms. Most assault weapon definitions are limited to rifles, but pistols or shotguns may also fall under the definition(s) or be specified by name.

Governing and defining laws include the now-expired Federal Assault Weapons Ban of 1994.

At that time, the U.S. Justice Department said, "In general, assault weapons are semiautomatic firearms with a large magazine of ammunition that were designed and configured for rapid fire and combat use.".

Clairette Rose
San Francisco
